description: Takes care of secutity and privacy. Also integrates a comment function for the entire WWW.

I don't have anything against the Gab Company and its attempts to foster a safe haven for any and all political speech. But you should probably pass on this one. It doesn't receive regular security updates and you are potentially putting your personal information at risk by trusting it here. This is not necessarily their fault, they have a small dev team, but nevertheless, this is a potentially dangerous browser pick and you should not use it even if you support the company in other ways.

This browser is a fork of Brave, which is itself a fork of Chromium. The key features of Brave are easily togglable privacy features, and a currency distribution mechanism that rewards you and the websites you visit via BAT crypto grants.

The privacy toggles here are identical to Brave's... with one problem... if you actually take advantage of the more important features, Gab's software will not work. Turning off scripts will break the Dissenter extension, disallowing tracking and cookies will break certain Gab features, and Gab Social blocks Tor entirely, if you prefer to browse anonymously. Brave is a good browser to base a fork off, just not necessarily for their goals. They would have done better to fork Firefox, which already has inbuilt security measures and consumes less resources than a Chromium base with more features

The Dissenter browser also scraps the reward system, and replaces it with their URL comment extension, which is a really cool idea, but its lack of adoption makes it little more than a novelty, and the core of the product has shifted to a news offshoot that integrates all the same features, you can just as easily use that on any browser (or if you can find it, download the browser extension and install it on your browser of choice. Though Gab has taken down their download link so you'll have to try to find it from a 3rd Party)

Maybe in the future, this will be the browser to go to. I trust this company not to datamine from their browser more than any other mainstream browsers, frankly. But until the team can assure regular security patches and fix compatibility with their own products, You're better off just using Brave or Firefox.
The title says it all. Firefox/Mozilla have decided to go down the path of censorship with Twitter, Facebook and Youtube.
summary: The only browser that supports freedom of speech
too many ads, use too much cpu

description: Browser was hacked and lost all my passwords and user ID's.

The Dissenter plugin is worth any and all issues you might have with this browser. Though I've never had any trouble out of it on any OS I've ever put it on. You can't complain about the quality and feature set of a free product when half the world has decided it no longer values your contributions and wants you dead.

Can't comment to a post on Facebook, Twitter, CBS/ABC/CNN or any other website?

Dissenter allows you to post comments anywhere, and to see others posted by Dissenter users.  Experience True Freedom of Speech!
summary: Comment on any article, even if blocked!

description: Want to leave a comment that will be permanent ( as long as the URL lives )? This is for you!
summary: This is the best browser in the universe

description: If you want to escape from the Big tech matrix with style. this browser is everything you need
summary: Fantastic browser, ultra fast and anti Big Tech Tyrants

description: I don't think Dissenter is the future. But something like it is. Big Tech continues to play Whack A Mole with expression and eventually they will miss
summary: Incredible idea, a preview of what the coming decades will be

description:
Would have been five stars except for two major reasons. First reason: Noone really uses it. After their extension got taken down lots of people just kind of gave up on them, so there's a lot less comments being posted lately. It's a bummer.

Also, as of late, YouTube doesn't behave properly. While Dissenter previously blocked YouTube ads, it now not only shows them, but they are all unskippable. I'm not sure if that's something YouTube did to combat adblock or a bug in Dissenter, but as I use YouTube very often and I don't want to watch ads I'm afraid I won't be using Dissenter for now.
ein toller Browser..wenn man ihn denn vernünftig zum laufen bekäme..seufz..
